snippet.textDisplay: For completely different reasons and circumstances, my parent's (and my entire family with them) didn't choose me either - in fact, they unchose me. It's been ten years. It was difficult at first, but I quickly found out who my real family was and it was found in my faith... in God and the church. Like raising children, parenting and relationships come with no manual, and one size does not fit all. For those of you with functioning, good families I commend you. For those without, we forge our own bonds through the day-to-day trials and events of life than bring us closer together.

snippet.textDisplay: I feel your pain.  My fiancée and I have been engaged for going on three years next month so you'd think my parents would have had enough time to get used to the idea when we sent out invitations a few weeks ago.  After they "prayed about it" (a week or two later) they decided they would go.  But no, they don't wanna talk about it.  And no, I'm not sure what to expect for my big day.  Navigating a gay wedding in a family full of pre-judgements is tough...  Cling to and depend on the people you know you can and make clear to the ones who judge you what they could be losing by not being there.  As Dan Savage always says, you can take yourself away from them as a punishment for them not accepting you as you are.  If they don't want to acknowledge your relationship (your life, your love), then you can show them a taste of what it's like without you in their lives.  Cause they'll feel that.  You're awesome!  Keep your chin up and know that their judgements say more about them than they do about you.  Stay proud.  <3

snippet.textDisplay: I have a half brother and half sister who have no relationship with their mother because they chose to distance themselves from that same "religion." My heart breaks for them and for you. I can't say I know how you feel but, like my brother and sister, I know that you have real family who care deeply about you. And I'm sure you know that, but it can't hurt to hear it again. As for the challenging and emotional complications that can come with wedding planning.. I just got married in October and I can't tell you the amount of drama that came out of the freaking woodwork. There was a moment the day before the wedding when my now husband and I thought that his mom may not come to the wedding. She had several difficult moments throughout the planning process that I think became very emotional for her and she handled them poorly and the day before the wedding she just casually decided she would opt out of coming to the rehearsal that evening even though she had a part in our ceremony. My husband said it was fine but I could tell that "fine" came with a lot of hurt and he was actually just fed up. It's not an easy thing to just forgive and forget moments like that and we still find ourselves needing to process some of the issues that came up with our family during wedding planning. My only advice is to try and embrace your wedding as a day that is truly just about you and your fiance. Your loved ones will share in that joy with you (or not) but nothing and nobody is more important than you two on that day. I know that seems obvious but every bride forgets it somewhere along the line - so here's your friendly reminder from a total stranger who just happened upon your video and felt the need to reach out lol.

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah we have loved you for years! We will always love you for you. My kids love you. I know it sucks when the people that are supposed to love is the most, just don’t love us in the right ways. I’ve been damaged and just now coming to terms at 41 with how those things effected me up to today. The baggage I’ve carried with me. It’s odd to me that it hurts me to say aloud I am enough or deserved to be loved because it frees a part of me that is still so damaged. I’m dropping my bags and those who can’t accept me for me. I cried with you! It’s not your fault that others can’t love without limitations, you have done nothing wrong. One of my best friends has escaped the witnesses so I understand the horrible things that go with it all. Just know..please.. that you have more love than you could ever know surrounding you. Feel that love coming to you on your special day and let it fill you up! We will all be sending it out in spades! This is only the third time I’ve ever been moved to make a comment on YouTube, but I had to because you are worth it! Much love from me and mine!

snippet.textDisplay:
I had a friend in high school who was a Jehovahs Witness and he was also in the process of coming to terms with his sexuality as a gay man. He struggled a lot with his identity because he knew his family would disown him. I watched him struggle and it made me incredibly sad for him. I believe he did eventually come out to his family and that he and his mom eventually patched things up.

Good for you for speaking out. I’m sure there are plenty of people who have and are still having this struggle with their family. And unfortunately it seems like religion often plays a big part in that.

You and Ella are going to have a beautiful wedding surrounded by those who love you unconditionally 💕

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, I am not sure if you’ll read my comment but I certainly needed to tell you this: I come from a very religious background & my religious community 100% consider being gay as a sin (choice), mental illness, perverted behaviour .. you name it,  and so my teenager self believed it. I was struggling in the inside with anxiety about “what was wrong with me” and internalized homophobia wishing that if i said it out-loud that “I like boys” I would successfully “pray the gay away”. At that time, when I googled “gay” in my native language, only +18 content or other anti gay content would pop up! Then i was brave enough to type the word in English and a less horrible content would pop up. Later, i discovered a bunch of coming out stories on youtube and was very obsessed! Smh I ended up discovering Hannah, this amazing, funny, bright, awesome, very authentic person who also happened to be GAY .. another person like me! A decent person that a teenager could look up to! Hannah you have always been one of the first youtubers who helped me feel more human. I deserved to feel that way and you NOW deserve to feel better, i wish i could help!

snippet.textDisplay:
We do not get to choose who our parents are. We do not get to choose how other people choose to see us. We can try as hard as we can to be ourselves and show that, but overall, we cannot choose what others think and feel. Your dad is a idiot for not actually seeing you for you instead of just looking at what his fucken religion thinks. I never understood why people choose religion over their own blood, their own kin. You didn't have to reach out to your Dad, you tried to let him into your life. Thats more then some people would do, and I am amazed how strong you were to try.
But, People who tell you that love is a crime, that love is immoral, that love is unnatural, they themselves, I feel, are not worth the time. They are not worth anything. I may not know your Father (And it sounds like its a good thing I don't know him) but he and his cult are not worth anything. He is not worth anything because he does not see the gift that God (the one he calls 'Creator and Supreme Being') has given him, you and your sister. The God he loves over everything gave him a Gift when you two were born, and he seems to not realize this. He fails in seeing what is right in front of him, the proof that God loves him with a gift of a wonderful daughter who is getting married and is successful in what she has become on Youtube, being a comedian, basically so many things! He is blind, completely blind. (HELL EVEN THE MORMON CHURCH changed their ideas of same sex couples, at least for the children of said families being able to be baptized while still within the family. Just had to bring that one up seeing as they are a pretty strict religion themselves from what I can tell. )
I know nothing I have said changes how your going to feel. Your Dad is your Dad after all and the feeling of wanting him to be there and be proud of who you are isn't something easy to understand, especially when I haven't been in the same shoes as you. But, You not only have your mother supporting you, you pretty much have all of us who are watching you as supporters too. I became a fan of your Drunk Kitchen series and stayed because of how amazing a person you are, especially when you are talking about things you are passionate about like your relationship and helping people who are in similar points in their life understand who they are.

I hope you have a amazing Wedding. And I know it may not mean much, but I am proud of you and I know a lot of your fans on here are proud of you in many more ways then one. <3 <3 <3

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who was raised in the Christian church, I understand what you are going through. I choose love even when it meant loosing my family and the people I grew up with. I just wanted to say that I study with Witnesses and have on and off all my life and believe in what they teach. However, I am a pangender, pansexual person. As much as I believe in this religion I also believe who a person loves is their own business. I think you are a wonderful person and I'm sorry you had to go through this kind of pain.

*Jehovah's Witnesses are not a cult, though there are some congregations that can be more extreme then others just like in many other religions. I wont say things like 'that could never happen here' or 'that isn't right' because there may in fact be places like that I've never seen myself. I would never think to invalidate something another person has been through or experienced. I can only say that for those who have suffered so, I am sorry. I hope the experience can be recovered from and your life happy. Because no matter what we are all entitled to our happiness.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m so sorry Hannah. You may feel that your dad and stepmom think that the witnesses are more important than you, but consider that they struggle with their own sense of identity. It might be too difficult for them to be “bad witnesses” or to sit with the discomfort that comes from acknowledging you AND being a part of a community that says you are bad. the result being that you get sh*t on, rejected—not because they are choosing the witnesses over you; they could be choosing to avoid the discomfort by neglecting this important day for you. You have nothing to be ashamed of, and you don’t deserve this pain.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can't imagine what you're going through and what you're feeling. To not have a parent at one of the happiest days of your life is heartbreaking and sad because you want them to be there to share in the joy and the love of finally being with the person you've chosen to live your life with. But when they aren't because of religious/political/etc reasons it's really hard to digest it but the most you can do is accept that they won't be there and go on with the event and have the best damn time that you can.

My mom was not openly homophobic, at least not what I can remember anyway, but I remember one phrase she had said to someone years ago that has stuck with me to this day: "I don't care if anyone else is gay/bi/etc but none of my kids will be that way." That scared me when I was in highschool because I had just discovered my bisexuality (which developed into pansexuality later in life) after much research and reflection but thankfully I never had to tell her because she died before I could come out to her. I'm just thankful that my dad is happy that I'm happy and that he's very accepting of who I am as a person and not who I choose to be attracted to.

Anyway, best of luck to you Hannah and I can't wait to see the beautiful wedding that you and Ella will have! 💜💜

As I Catholic I find this kind of a situation so hard. My religion teaches me to love others as the creator and ruler of the universe would love them. The Catholic teaching is that pure love which is shared between two human beings cannot be evil or wrong. But once that shared love goes beyond the boundaries of natural creation it becomes wrong. My heart aches for you and I can’t even imagine your pain. But I do respect religion and I sincerely hope you know that there are many many religious in the world who want nothing but joy, peace, and happiness for you and your loved ones.
If you or anyone may be intrigued about any catholic teaching, Fr. Mike Schmitz is absolutely wonderful!
I would like you to know I admire your honestly and I truly wish happiness for you and everyone you love!
- a Catholic

snippet.textDisplay:
I am as straight as can be but feel that I can understand your pain. My father left prior to my birth...and never bothered to visit or support us. When I was 16, my oldest brother died. An aunt thought my father had a right to know, so she called him. And when he came to our front door, I thought he was a salesman and left him standing on the front porch on a cold, rainy Indiana early spring day.
He stayed for the funeral -- my mother was gracious enough to provide him a bed. He heard that my brother had some life insurance. My father returned 2 months later for "his" share. How he could honestly think he deserved anything escapes my mind. He had left my mother to provide for 4 children on her own for 16 years!
The joke was on him however. My pin-headed brother had made his girlfriend his beneficiary so her daughter could go to college. She was good enough to pay for the funeral.
So, I know about parental rejection. I know the pain and the trauma it causes. Please know that you are much more than anything your father may have shared in creating you. You are who you make yourself to be.
My hope is that you might find peace. Your father is a very small man...he is the loser. But who you are and take pride in the good things that you are.

snippet.textDisplay: I may not be in the exact position as you because I’m not getting married and/or interested in women, but I know how you feel. I grew up as a Jehovah’s Witness and having my mum come out of the religion and me following in her foot steps it has put a big wall between my dad and I. I can’t go to concert tomorrow with him because of the genre of music they are. Even though it seems small, it’s a big thing for me because it’s something I am interested in and I can’t do that with him because if he does choose to go with me he could be judged or betraying Jehovah and it breaks my heart. I have stopped being a witness about 7 years ago because I realised how controlled I felt, when I knew people wouldn’t be happy about the choices I make for my life. It is frowned upon to go to University, it is frowned upon to date/marry someone who is not involved with the religion, it is frowned upon to give or take blood for medical situations, there are so many things I could list. I didn’t want to live my life where multiple or one person could control the choices I make so I chose to leave and I also have to deal with the fact that my dad cannot celebrate my birthday with me, or Christmas, and he may not even attend my wedding because there is a huge chance I will marry someone who is not a Jehovah’s Witness! It is a hard life as a witness. I am glad that you know that you cannot be controlled, and you can control your own life. Also, I agree Jehovah’s Witnesses are like a cult....

snippet.textDisplay: Hannah, you don't know me from the stranger at the airport. I'm also probably going to be a voice lost in a cacophony of voices, but I understand your pain. I've lost both of my parents to the politics of the day and the right wing version of religion at this point. I feel more often than not like an orphan. I love them, I have moments where I agonize over knowing I have to cut them out of my life just to be me, be happy, and live how I need to. I've watched you for a long time and have celebrated when you've celebrated. This hurts me on a level I didn't expect because I KNOW this pain intimately and it's all just been in the last month that it all finally blew up in my face. I don't know you, but I love you. You don't know me, but I care about you. I'm not sure what I can say to even begin to help with the hurt because I wouldn't wish this on my worst enemy, but I'm here to cheer you on, to support you, and be a voice that says you aren't alone. No matter how small my voice will be, I say it because we all need that one voice. I look forward to your big day and what you will share with us. No child should have to feel this pain.

snippet.textDisplay:
You are wonderful, and you are loved. I know there's no replacement for a parent, but there are so many people who love and cherish you and all that you bring into this world. "Buffering" remains one of the most important books I've ever read, and it was a significant part of my eventual decision to come out both for the support it gave me, and because I push a few important people in my life to read it to get a better sense of what I was doing when I finally did come out. I am so sorry that you've been forced into this position, and I'm sorry that your father is incapable of understanding how wonderful you are. You have had my undying appreciation and respect for years now, and this video just reinforces that further. Your commitment to living truly and openly means so much to so many, and I personally thank you for the help you have given me by doing so. What you do every day takes such courage, and that courage is seen and appreciated.



(While I don't know anyone in the Witnesses, I will be watching that documentary tonight. Thanks for putting it on my radar.)

I saw the Oxygen documentary and cried realizing thousands of other victims have been harmed, humiliated and abandoned. I’m so glad light is being shed on this dark evil.

That said, please know you are not alone and your feelings are valid! I’m still hurt by my parents rejection and putting the organization first even after all this time. You have every right to feel upset, sad & angry.

I never knew about you until today, by EX JW Analyzer. I’m glad I saw this. Don’t let your dad or anyone ruin your beautiful day. Thank you for sharing your story and bringing awareness. So many people think JW’s are sweet people that just want to save souls. Truth is they destroy our spirits and break up families. So sorry you’re going through this. Stay strong and don’t let this get you too down. We stand by you!

snippet.textDisplay: My wife and I got married 4 years ago on March 12. My parents are witnesses as well and they did not come to our wedding. March 12 also happens to be my mothers birthday and I guess that wasn’t such a great idea to get married on her birthday because last year she was diagnosed with cancer and she passed away and now every wedding anniversary I will think about my mom and her birthday and the fact that she’s dead and the fact that they refused to come to our wedding. I was very confused when my parents said they would not come to our wedding because when marriage equality passed my mom seemed really happy and they’ve always welcomed anyone that I was dating into their house and they had gone to one of my brothers weddings he had been married twice and his second wedding was actually in a Catholic church and my parents decided that that was OK but it was not OK to go to a same-sex wedding. When my parents told me they were not going to come to our wedding I was really hurt and really upset and I decided that I would not be able to have a relationship with them going forward and I didn’t talk to them for about three months and then my mom and I started sending text messages to each other and eventually my wife and I went down to see them and I continued to have a relationship with them even though it was painful but I am very grateful that I did not cut my parents out of my life because my mom is now dead and had I done that I wouldn’t of had the last three years to spend time with her. I love my parents but I despise their religion.

snippet.textDisplay: I remember being in hosptial a couple of years ago, I was really poorly and was told to go in after seeing my GP my Dad came and my husband was there, my mum worked at the hospital that I was in, she did come down and see me, but just talked to my Dad and my husband the whole time, my husband got her to hold my hand and it felt AMAZING like something on another level, like only a connection that a mother could have with her child, I felt so calm and knew I was going to be alright, its like a very raw natural feeling, I want this I want my mum to hold me and love me. But she still doesn't. I don't expect anything from her but still I would love to have a relationship with her. My head gets it, but my heart still wants it.

snippet.textDisplay: In January, my mom disowned me. She said she wanted nothing to do with me anymore. It was painful. But I wasn't surprised. This shit has been going on for 22 years. I used to get locked up as a kid. Spent 7 years of my life in a closet under the stairs. It hurts so bad to be told by your own parents that no one could love you. They tried to convince me that my girlfriend doesn't love me. Me and her have been together in our same sex relationship for 2 years now. But my while family chose religion over me. I'm so sorry you've had to deal with this rejection. I'm here for you if you ever want to talk. I know I'm just another subscriber, but I mean it.

snippet.textDisplay: This hurts because our parents are our first bond, our foundation for self-esteem, and our initial connection between ourselves and the outside world. They're our first loves and our first disappointments. We cultivate and maintain a bond with our parents, even when they betray us or let us down because ultimately it's a deep, meaningful relationship whether it functions as we need, or not. You're in mourning, it's a significant loss, and you have to let yourself go through that process. It's a vein of mourning that could stay with you through the important moments in your life, but you're a kind, articulate, intelligent woman, and are very very loved, so have every capacity to transcend your bereavement. Feel your feelings, shamelessly. Thank you for sharing, Hannah. It's a gift. With love <3

May the love of all we who love to hear you act as building blocks to a safe and loving space for you and anyone else ostracized by those who are meant to love us the most.

snippet.textDisplay: My 25 year old son AJ came out to me as gay when he was 12. He trusted I would accept and affirm him which is exactly what I did and it’s brought us even closer and has made me a better person and mom.  AJ made the decision not to tell the rest of our family knowing as Evangelical Christians they would likely reject him. The majority are senior pastors whose churches actually believe the lie that the LGBTQ community are going to hell.  Unfortunately that decision was taken away from him when his Aunt betrayed him in the summer of 2018 by outing him to our mom. AJ was immediately disowned by our entire family on both sides including his father after they found out he is gay. My mom also disowned and disinherited me when I refused to abandon my son or withdraw my support of the LGBTQ community. Unfortunately because AJ and I were living on family property and working in the family business we lost literally everything having to leave our home only with what we could physically carry off the property.  We didn’t just loose items of value but irreplaceable keepsakes and mementos like family photos. My family refuses to return any of it! We would have been homeless if it wasn’t for a generous, kind hearted friend who has become my chosen sister and AJ’s Aunt. I wish I could say things got better but my mom and her husband began a hate campaign directed at AJ by sending the most vile, disgusting hate letters, texts and emails. I will never forget the sound of my grown son crying like a baby as he literally fell to the floor after reading just the first few lines. Yes, they really were that bad! My son is the kindest most compassionate young man you’ve ever met and he adored his grandmother. Her rejection has caused scars that will last a lifetime. I knew my mom would never accept having a gay grandson but never in a million years did I dream she’d be so hateful to AJ of all people. He was her favorite until she found out he’s gay.  In January 2019 I was forced to call 911 after my brother-in-law and step-father broke into our home and physically assaulted my son while calling him ugly gay slurs and telling him he was going to hell.  You can listen to this 911 call on my “channel.” AJ is out to everyone now (I couldn’t be more proud of my son!) so we’re both very open about what we’ve experienced in hopes it will help someone else who has experienced the pain of family betrayal and rejection. Grieving the loss of loved ones who are still very much alive has been excruciatingly painful but we are both healing and doing much better. There was a point I didn’t know if my son would even survive this trauma because his depression became so severe he didn’t want to live. Thankfully he’s smiling and laughing again and we’ve both met wonderful people along this journey who have become family. Sorry this is so long. 🤭 I don’t comment often but when I do I tend to go on and on.

snippet.textDisplay: It is definitely a cult. When a religion tears a family apart that is exactly what it is. I was born in that religion and I always knew I was gay and I also knew if they knew that I would be kicked out or sent somewhere to "pray the gay away." I have a very big family and most of them have dropped my like a bag of dirt. Last things some of my sister's have said is "even if I was worldly I wouldn't wanna know about ur disgusting life." Even my twin sister said "I'd rather u dead then gay." Those things have stuck w me thru the years. But I hold onto the ones who love me for who I am. Family isn't always blood. I may have lost alot but I have gained so much more. Hold onto that! Hold onto ur soon to be wife and the memories u both will be making. I am beyond proud of u! Keep ur chin up and know u have alot of ppl in ur corner cheering u on!

I wonder why that is?

Here is some red letter scripture for you:

““Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door of the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor will you let those enter who are trying to.

“Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel over land and sea to win a single convert, and when you have succeeded, you make them twice as much a child of hell as you are...
…“Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You build tombs for the prophets and decorate the graves of the righteous. And you say, ‘If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.’ So you testify against yourselves that you are the descendants of those who murdered the prophets. Go ahead, then, and complete what your ancestors started! “You snakes! You brood of vipers! How will you escape being condemned to hell?”
‭‭Matthew‬ ‭23

snippet.textDisplay: The statement you made of Jehova's witnesses holding themselves above the law is very true. Military service is obligatory in Finland for men who have turned 18. Jehova's witnesses are the only people who are allowed to not complete the obligatory military service because of their religion. All other Finnish men who are capable, no matter if they're Muslim, Christian or Jew, have to complete the military service or do a year of civil service. If they won't do it they'll end up in jail. The witnesses have been able to avoid it for years and no one questions it. They don't even have to do civil service and are freed of everything. No jail time, no nothing.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is a GORGEOUS photographer named Shelbie Dimond on Instagram who is 3rd generation Witness. Her father disowned her in front of the elders when she was 14 and she became an apostate. Her parents, friends, extended family, entire community have rejected her, and have taken to reporting her images on multiple Instagram accounts (I'm talking shadowbanned for YEARS on MULTIPLE accounts with 20K+ followers), resulting in her losing income, jobs, and homes/living situations. She has suffered immensely at the hands of this cult, and in the five years that I've followed her journey I've never felt more helpless or sad for an artist. There are countless people all over the world that are harassed, bullied, manipulated by their own family members for YEARS after they walk away from the organization. This is not a religion. This is dangerous.

Thank you for brining light to a tragic situation, Hannah, for voicing your truth and thereby elevating the voices of others who haven't been heard. You are so loved, radically and unapologetically. My heart is with you as you navigate this heartbreak, and I hope you know that there is endless grace for the journey you've been on and will continue down with your partner Ella. I love you. There is a GORGEOUS photographer named Shelbie Dimond on Instagram who is 3rd generation Witness. Her father disowned her in front of the elders when she was 14 and she became an apostate. Her parents, friends, extended family, entire community have rejected her, and have taken to reporting her images on multiple Instagram accounts (I'm talking shadowbanned for YEARS on MULTIPLE accounts with 20K+ followers), resulting in her losing income, jobs, and homes/living situations. She has suffered immensely at the hands of this cult, and in the five years that I've followed her journey I've never felt more helpless or sad for an artist. There are countless people all over the world that are harassed, bullied, manipulated by their own family members for YEARS after they walk away from the organization. This is not a religion. This is dangerous.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm so proud of you for facing and trying to overcome the pains you are facing in your life.
My grandfather is a Jehovah's Witness as well and there are stories that I can't begin to describe how distressing, disgusting they were.
He is a kind and pleasant man, but what he follows is full of spite.
I don't know if he's aware of my relationships (whether that's with a man, a woman, or someone else on the spectrum of gender) or religious views, etc... I don't want to know.
I have felt the pain of rejection from other family members and friends for parts of me that I can't have any control over. And it's not my fault that those people can't be open or caring enough to try and understand.
It is not your fault either.
I wish you all the love and care and support that you need. It's never easy, but having a community to support and love you makes a difference. That's something that you have provided to so many people and I hope that they are able to find those things as well.
Live your truth, so you can learn to love and accept yourself.
